 The discourses of moral philosophers are virtually predicated on the
 existence of "absolutes" - about what "ought" to be done etc. In 
 this special and restricted sense, there is no reason why "absolutes"
 cannot be discussed with the utmost gravity.
 Scientific discourse, however, admits no absolutes: by definition a
 science is open-ended, provisional, and probabilistic. All "answers"
 about the material universe - even those concerning the elementary
 particles - are subject to revision in the light of new observations and
 experiments.

 It is still incorrect to say that "science admits no absolutes" The use of the word "no" makes that statement, about science, an absolute. 
 
 It is perfectly resonable to say that science is not exact. But is based on probability and statistics and draws conclusions from that. It is okay to say that it is not the job of science to make absolute claims about the universe but one must understand that science, in fact, does make absolute claims. Many scientists take a theory and declare it a law after it stands the test of time. Most scientists that I have debated here would declare evolution to be a fact as opposed to a theory with probabilities etc. Science makes absolute statements and to claim that science is not about absolutes takes one down the path of self denial.

 Semantics. Language's primary goal is for communication. We also don't tend to write everything in legal terms, you know...hundred page documents just to say one simple thing. Why? Efficiency. While your strict definitions of the words in the phrase are an interesting exercise in logic, it doesn't take into account that language isn't an absolutely perfect form of communication. 
 
 Here is one definition:
 Law: A term normally used in technology for an extreme form of theory that claims absolute predictability of cause and effect, as presented in formal scientific statements such as Newton's Laws of Gravitation. Practical experience indicates that the only true law is that there are no absolute laws, since all events are infinitely interlinked in the total field, and all cause/effect chains are subject to infinite regress. In practice, 'laws' are best understood as useful guidelines, describing probable performance to a high, but never absolute, degree of certainty. 
 
 Best understood as useful guidelines and not for semantic word abuse.
 
 
 Re-stated: "There are no absolutes"
 
 Are you suggesting that everyone saying this is denying that 2+2=4? Do you think that's what's being communicated? No, I don't think they are. I think they are saying "aside from these things over here, things like evil and good, don't seem to be absolutes." It's a phrase, it is efficient to say it with the understanding that someone won't make a tiresome interperetation of it.
 
 Absolute is too strong a word using your strict definition (That doesn't seem to be an absolute definition), but good luck changing the phrase. "Most things are imprecise". Great, but sorry, language requires understanding culture, especially in the case of one sentence describing a very complex idea.
 
 Here's another one:
 "In the study of logic, something observed similarly by most observers, or something agreed upon, or which has the same value each time measured. "
 
 "The only absolute is that there are no other absolutes".
 
 It's just semantic games. I think I understand the meaning, and I don't need a 20 page thread to describe it.

 No need to go that far...
 "Q I thought evolution was just a theory. Why do you call it a fact? 
 A Biological evolution is a change in the genetic characteristics of a population over time. That this happens is a fact. Biological evolution also refers to the common descent of living organisms from shared ancestors. The evidence for historical evolution -- genetic, fossil, anatomical, etc. -- is so overwhelming that it is also considered a fact. The theory of evolution describes the mechanisms that cause evolution. So evolution is both a fact and a theory. See the Evolution is a Fact and a Theory FAQ, the Introduction to Evolutionary Biology FAQ and the Five Major Misconceptions about Evolution FAQ: Evolution is Only a theory."
 http://www.talkorigins.org/origins/faqs-qa.html
 
 The problem is it can't be falsified, because every instance in nature is believed to have come into being by evolution, so even if you find something that's inconsistant, they'll say 'nope, evolution did that too!'

 The problem is it can't be falsified, because every instance in nature is believed to have come into being by evolution, so even if you find something that's inconsistant, they'll say 'nope, evolution did that too!'
 
 Mach has an interesting definition of 'science fiction'; mixing it up with science - as in the pursuit of exobiology.

 
 It's because the languge is hard to capture as non-scientists (speaking for me and possibly others on the board).
 
 The process of evolution in general terms: change over time, is a "fact". It's not something that can be proven or disproven. It's like discussing a "bell curve" distribution in statistics, it just is. It's just a word to describe a process.
 
 Same goes for evolution being termed change in allele frequencey in a population. It's just a term, it's not "claiming" anything, it's descriptive.
 
 Sometimes we summarize and aren't verbose, and just talk about the evolution of all life on earth as a broad concept. Fact also has many definitions. Some of these definitions can be applied to the theory of evolution, others cannot, by definition, depending on your choice of definitions.
 
 So it all depends on what accuracy you're going for, and what definition of evolution you're referring to. No surprise that it's so often misrepresented, or interpereted as being incorrect.
 
 I think claiming life started spontaneously is still less a fact and more a theory, but certainly not something that any scientist perceives as being beyond the physical world. Maybe that's the non-factual part of evolution you've got the gripe with.
 
 ==========

 I think others have similarly tried this before. I have argued this point logically for a while now. 
 
 The two statements are contradictory and therefore apply the fallacy of inconsistency. Therefore, illogical. No absolutes is disproven by proving the existence of even one absolute. If you state there is only one absolute and that is that there are no absolutes, the first half disproves the second.
 
 Similarly, if there are absolutes then there must be at least two. 1) There are absolutes. 2) Anything else that is not #1 but is still absolute. 
 
 The question of whether or not we can know what the absolutes are.....NOW that is a different situation all together and quite arguable.
